Sección
What's wrong?

Prerequisite knowledge refers to the knowledge learners should already have in order to be able to effectively complete the learning. Examples of pre-knowledge can be:
  • Learners must have level 4 English
  • Learners must be able to assemble standard power tools
Describe the prerequisite knowledge learners should have to effectively complete this learning.

If you look at the images, can you recognize at first sight what the problem is? 

Do you think there is a solution to each problem? How would you solve each problem?

When you go into a hospital, you might find lots of different people, people with different health problems. You will meet lots of people there; from the moment you arrive until you’re ready to leave.

You might meet as many as 30 people or more just in one day! You’ll see plenty of doctors and nurses too.

People go to the hospital for many reasons. It may seem a little scary to go to a hospital, but doctors, nurses, and other hospital workers are there to help people who are sick to feel better.

Let's find more about this topic...  

Survey

Wait! Not so fast...

This activity is destined for English I (A2 level), if you have a lower level it might be difficult for you to comprehend and answer some activities. 

Now continue at your own risk...   ---->
What will you learn?
University of Auckland
Objectives describe the expected outcomes of the learning and should define what the learners will be able to do when they have completed the learning tasks.
Type the learning objectives for this resource.

• In this material you will learn how to use the verb should in affirmative, negative and interrogative sentences by answering some activities. 
  • You will learn vocabulary about the most common health problems.
  • You will learn how to give recommendations by using the modal verb should.
Previous knowledge
Before we continue...

Prerequisite knowledge refers to the knowledge learners should already have in order to be able to effectively complete the learning. Examples of pre-knowledge can be:
  • Learners must have level 4 English
  • Learners must be able to assemble standard power tools
Describe the prerequisite knowledge learners should have to effectively complete this learning.

Before you learn the uses of  the verb should , let's make sure you understand what a modal verb is. Do you remember how to use the verb can? Well, can is a modal verb. 

A modal verb is a verb used with another verb to express an idea, such as possibility, that is not expressed by the main verb.

Answer the next activities to test yourself and see if you remember how to use this verb (can).
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.

After that, click on "Submit" to check your answers. If they are marked in green, they are correct; but if your answers are marked in red, there is something wrong.

You can click on "Restart" to answer the activity again. 

To see the correct answers click on "Show answers".

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.

Do not forget! 

Can is a modal verb, to create affirmative sentences we follow this structure: 

Subject  +  can  +  * verb  +  complement.  

* it is not necessary to put to before the verb.
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.

Turn the given sentences into negative sentences or questions. The phrases  tell you what to do. (Remember to use capital letters at the beginning of the sentences) Do not use contractions.

EXAMPLE:

He can correct the mistakes. → negative sentence

ANSWER:

He cannot correct the mistakes.

When you finish completing the sentences click on "Submit" to evaluate your answers. If they are marked in green, they are correct; but if your answers are marked in red, there is something wrong. 

You can click on "Restart" to answer the activity again. 

To see the correct answers click on "Show answers".
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

The girls cannot play hockey . 

2. Richard can play the trumpet. → question

Can Richard play the trumpet ?

3. He can write good stories. → negative sentence

He cannot write good stories . 

4. Alex can write exciting articles. → question

Can Alex write exciting articles ?

5. She can write with her left hand → negative sentence

She cannot write with her left hand .

6. Henry can cook spaghetti. → question

Can Henry cook spaghetti ?

7. They can cook well. → negative sentence

They cannot cook well.

8. Antonio can play videogames.  → question

Can Antonio play videogames ?

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.

Do not forget!

Can is a modal verb, to form sentences in negative you need: 

Subject  +  cannot  (can't) +  *verb  +  complement.

To make questions or interrogative sentences you follow this structure: 

Can  +  subject  +  *verb  +  complement?

* The verb needs to be in the base form

If you completed the previous activities correctly, the rest will be no problem!

Let's continue...
Modal verb "should"

Read the information, if it is necessary take notes in your portfolio. After that, answer the activities with the information given.

When do we use this verb?

We use should when we want to show what is right, appropriate, etc., especially when criticizing somebody’s actions.

  • You shouldn't drink and drive.                              
  • He should be more careful.

We use should when we want to give or ask for advice (recommendation).

  • You should stop worrying about it.
  • Should I call him and apologize? 

Structure of should

We will now study the construction of affirmative, negative, and interrogative sentences using the modal auxiliary should.

  • Affirmative sentences

  • Negative sentences

  • Interrogative sentences

YES/NO questions

Wh.. questions

Note that:

  • The auxiliary verb should is invariable. There is only one form: should 

    Be careful:  It is imposible to say shoulds

We don't say: She shoulds go to school.                            We say: She should go to school. 

  • The main verb is usually in the base form (He should go).

Be careful: we do not add  to  before the main verb. 

We don't say: You should to go to school.                                       We say: You should go to school.     

  • There is no short form for should, but we can shorten the negative should not to shouldn't.

We can say: I should not eat many candies.                 We can also say: I shouldn't eat many candies.

True/false questions present a statement where the learner must decide if the statement is true. This type of question works well for factual information and information that lends itself to either/or responses.

If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

1. You should go to the opera in London. It’s great. (go)

2. You should not tell her about it. It’s too depressing. (not tell)

3. You should not cross the street at red traffic lights. (not cross)

4. You should spend less money on clothes. They’re too expensive. (spend)

5. That’s a fantastic book. You should read it. (read)

6. It is cold. You should wear a cardigan. (wear)

7. Should I buy  the dress or the skirt? (I / buy) 

8. Our neighbors are having a big fight. Should we call the police? (we / call)

Give advice
University of Auckland
Provide relevant feedback on the situation.

A case study is a device that provides learners with a simulation that has an educational basis. It takes a situation, generally based in reality, and asks learners to demonstrate or describe what action they would take to complete a task or resolve a situation. The case study allows learners apply their own knowledge and experience to completing the tasks assigned. when designing a case study consider the following:
  • What educational points are conveyed in the story
  • What preparation will the learners need to do prior to working on the case study
  • Where the case study fits into the rest of the course
  • How the learners will interact with the materials and each other e.g. if run in a classroom situation can teams be setup to work on different aspects of the case and if so how are ideas feed back to the class
Describe the activity tasks relevant to the case story provided. These could be in the form of questions or instructions for activity which may lead the learner to resolving a dilemma presented.

Create the case story. A good case is one that describes a controversy or sets the scene by describing the characters involved and the situation. It should also allow for some action to be taken in order to gain resolution of the situation.
C:\Program Files (x86)\exe\images\empty.gif

Create the case story. A good case is one that describes a controversy or sets the scene by describing the characters involved and the situation. It should also allow for some action to be taken in order to gain resolution of the situation.

Read the information, if it is necessary take notes in your notebook. 

Asking for advice

One way to ask for advice is using the modal  verb SHOULD.

We can make this type of question using …

Should I + verb…?

For example:

Should I stay or Should I go?

The question Should I…? … means I want advice or a recommendation about something. 

Should I wear the green shirt? (I am asking for your advice or recommendation).

We can also have the Wh- words like What, When, Why, etc. before the modal verb.

For example: What should we do now? (What do you suggest?) 

How can we give advice?

One common way to respond to a question with SHOULD is to also use SHOULD in the answer.

You can start by saying:

I think you should + verb*

* Remember, as mentioned in the last section, the verb is in the base form of the infinitive.

For example: 

I think you should study more. 

Here you are giving advice.

You can also use other subjects like:

  • I think he should…
  • I think we should…
  • I think they should…

How about when we want to give advice about what NOT to do. Here we use:

I DON’T think you should + verb.

  • I don’t think you should go.
  • I don’t think you should stay.

BUT be careful. We CANNOT say …

  • I think you SHOULDN’T + verb. (No, this is NOT correct).

In English we do NOT use shouldn’t after I think.
Scrambled List

Put the conversation between Tomek and Gabi in the right order. Use the arrows on the right to decide to move each sentence up or down. After you finish placing the sentences in the correct order, click on "check" to see if you completed the conversation correctly.

  • Tomek: I think we’re lost!
  • Gabi: Oh no! What should we do?
  • Tomek: Well, we shouldn't worry. I think we should ask someone for directions.
  • Gabi: That’s a good idea. Who should we ask?
  • Tomek: I don't know. Should we ask the lady overthere?
  • Gabi: Sure! I think we should do that.
  • Tomek: Excuse me! Can you tell us how to get to the Anthropology National Museum?
  • Lady: You should take a taxi, it is really far from here.
  • Gabi: She is right. I don’t think you should go walking, let's take a taxi.

Right!

Interactive Activities
Common health problems
University of Auckland

The Reading Activity will primarily be used to check a learner's comprehension of a given text. This can be done by asking the learner to reflect on the reading and respond to questions about the reading, or by having them complete some other possibly more physical task based on the reading.

Teachers should keep the following in mind when using this iDevice:

  1. Think about the number of different types of activity planned for your resource that will be visually signalled in the content. Avoid using too many different types or classification of activities otherwise learner may become confused. Usually three or four different types are more than adequate for a teaching resource.
  2. From a visual design perspective, avoid having two iDevices immediately following each other without any text in between. If this is required, rather collapse two questions or events into one iDevice.
  3. Think about activities where the perceived benefit of doing the activity outweighs the time and effort it will take to complete the activity.
Enter the details of the reading including reference details. The referencing style used will depend on the preference of your faculty or department.
What to read

Usually when we are not feeling well, we go to the doctor, but sometimes we take advice from our family members or friends because we do  not consider that pain a big problem. There can be many reasons why a person asks for recommendations when we talk about health. As you know there are many illnesses and health problems. Here you have an illustrated list of some common health problems. If you have problems to understand a word, click here to know its meaning.
Describe the tasks related to the reading learners should undertake. This helps demonstrate relevance for learners.
Use feedback to provide a summary of the points covered in the reading, or as a starting point for further analysis of the reading by posing a question or providing a statement to begin a debate.

Read the question or the sentence and select the best option to complete the idea in each of the situations. Do not forget the rules and the vocabulary that you learned in the previous sections. You can use the dictionary if you do not understand something.
Enter the available choices here. You can add options by clicking the "Add Another Option" button. Delete options by clicking the red "X" next to the Option.
University of Auckland

Type in the feedback that you want the student to see when selecting the particular option. If you don't complete this box, eXe will automatically provide default feedback as follows: "Correct answer" as indicated by the selection for the correct answer; or "Wrong answer" for the other options.
Enter a hint here. If you do not want to provide a hint, leave this field blank.
Select the correct option by clicking on the radio button.

Although more often used in formal testing situations MCQs can be used as a testing tool to stimulate thought and discussion on topics students may feel a little reticent in responding to. When designing a MCQ test consider the following:
  • What learning outcomes are the questions testing
  • What intellectual skills are being tested
  • What are the language skills of the audience
  • Gender and cultural issues
  • Avoid grammar language and question structures that might provide clues
Enter the question stem. The quest should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.

When building an MCQ consider the following:
  • Use phrases that learners are familiar with and have encountered in their study
  • Keep responses concise
  • There should be some consistency between the stem and the responses
  • Provide enough options to challenge learners to think about their response
  • Try to make sure that correct responses are not more detailed than the distractors
  • Distractors should be incorrect but plausible
Enter the question stem. The quest should be clear and unambiguous. Avoid negative premises as these can tend to be ambiguous.

Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).
University of Auckland

Reflection is a teaching method often used to connect theory to practice. Reflection tasks often provide learners with an opportunity to observe and reflect on their observations before presenting these as a piece of academic work. Journals, diaries, profiles and portfolios are useful tools for collecting observation data. Rubrics and guides can be effective feedback tools.
Enter a question for learners to reflect upon.
Reflective question:

What would you recommend to someone who has a health problem?

Now select five common health problems. Write them in your notebook.  For each health problem, write two recommendations using the modal verb should, one recommendation using the verb in affirmative, and the other one using the negative form of the verb.

For example: 

Health problem What you should do?  What you should not do?
headache  You should take an aspirin.  You shouldn't listen to loud music.

Once you finish the activity, ask your teacher to check your sentences (recommendations). 

Keep in mind that you can use the verb should to give advice or recommendation in any situation, not just for health problems.

You made it to the end. Good job!
Describe how learners will assess how they have done in the exercise (rubrics are useful devices for providing reflective feedback).

  1. To get this activity validated, you must score at least 80% in this quiz.
  2. In order not to lose points, it is important to check not only your answer but your spelling too.
